Derek,

A friend of mine has implemented an InF module (as well as the
Izhikevich spiking model) for our NEAT Python project. I'm not very
familiar with them, but she's been working with these models in her
research.

You can browse the source code of our project here:
http://code.google.com/p/neat-python/source/browse -- what you want is
in /trunk/neat/ifnn. The code is a mix of Python and C++, but there is
a "pure python" version of the InF and some C++ bindings. You can
easily understand the sources since Python is "almost" like
pseudo-code :-)

Hope it helps!

Cesar

On Thu, Jun 19, 2008 at 1:45 AM, Derek James <djames@...> wrote:
> Hey all,
>
> I've just recently started working with leaky integrate-and-fire (LIF)
> neurons, and since I don't have any prior experience with them and I'm
> relying on written resources, I thought I'd post a quick question here
> to see if anybody else had done much work with them. I have a few
> questions regarding their implementation, as well as spike-time
> dependent plasticity (STDP).
>
> We've got almost 400 members now in the group...anybody have any
> experience implementing these things?
>
> Thanks,
> Derek
